awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Traffic Analyzer for Visualization and Simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project focuses on assessing state-of-the-art technologies in artificial intelligence and computer vision for traffic visualization and simulation. This is important since the construction demands keep increasing in the post-pandemic era. At the moment, many simulators used the mock-up data or random data. Meanwhile, consulting firms still deploy humans using manual clickers to count vehicles in a period of several days or weeks. This process is time and labor consuming. This project will explore implementation and commercialization opportunities with a traffic analysis tool to visualize and simulate the traffic from the analyzed data. 

This I-Corps project develops a system to analyze the traffic cameras. It applies state-of-the-art computer vision algorithms from object detection to trajectory-based tracking in order to improve the performance of traffic flow estimation. The technology analyzes the camera data in the context of a graph; the traffic of one node can affect another node in the traffic graph. Significantly, the visual data taken from one city camera grid can be used for other cities where the traffic situation remains the same. The technology also includes a city traffic planning simulator using the analyzed traffic data. The simulator is used to support metropolitan transportation planning. The addition or removal of any traffic infrastructure can be observed from the simulator. Therefore, the simulator results can guide engineers and city authorities in urban development planning.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Traffic visualization and simulation are needed for urban planning, traffic management, public safety, and smart city development to optimize traffic flow and enhance transportation systems. The current methods of traffic analysis still rely on outdated data or manual data collection. Therefore, we have developed an automated traffic analyzer for both visualization and simulation, making the traffic analysis task faster and more accurate. Our system automatically analyzes traffic cameras, applies state-of-the-art artificial intelligence algorithms from object detection to trajectory-based tracking, to enhance traffic flow estimation. In addition, our system includes a city traffic planning simulator that utilizes the analyzed traffic data to support metropolitan transportation planning. The simulator allows city authorities to assess the impact of adding or removing traffic infrastructure, providing valuable insights for city planners and engineers in urban development decision making.

In this project, we validate the market potential of our system and its commercialization through customer discovery. As we participated in the NSF I-Corps program, our team conducted over 100 customer discovery interviews with city planners, builders, state department of transportation officials, engineers, and consultants. These discussions gave us an insightful look into the market needs and technical requirements for deploying our traffic analyzer for visualization and simulation. The feedback also led to a strategic focus on customer segments such as traffic engineers from consulting firms who are interested in our system. In addition, the I-Corps customer discovery process has offered valuable insights that have guided our other NSF proposal submissions and contributed to our research advancement in the fields of artificial intelligence, visualization and simulation. Our future plans are to improve our system and seek support through NSF SBIR/STTR, PFI grants, as well as other funding opportunities from state and regional innovation programs.

 


Last Modified: 03/05/2025
Modified by: Tam Nguyen
